issues.title: add type field to requests + registry
issues.author: fpalombini
issues.body:
AP22: The proposal is to add a “Type” field to requests, as we have enough types to motivate that (key distribution request, leave request, update key request, new key request). We will register the different types in a new IANA registry. The two new types are intended for current group members and are the following:

* “update”: the node can send it to get updated keying material (might get back the same, if it didn't change).

* “new”: the node can send it to retrieve a *new* key id, if it needs new keying material (e.g. seq numbers have wrapped around, expiration, etc).

We will also remove the “leave” field as that is not needed anymore.

issues.title: When are the public key  and proof of possession required to be present
issues.author: jimsch
issues.body:
I believe that one needs to look at the following cases:

1.  No public key with the right parameters has been associated with the token - in this case both the key and proof are required
2.  One public key with the right parameters has been associated with the token - in this case the following would seem to be fine a) neither are present, b) just the key is present (proof already has been done), c) both are present
3. Multiple public keys with the right parameters have been associated with the token - In this case the following would seem to be fine a) just the key is present (proof has already been done) or b) both are present

Such a change would seem to maximize the number of times that the public key can be omitted and an even greater number of times the proof can be omitted.  In the event that the proof is needed, the error would return a new server nonce to be used in the re-sent join message.

comments.author: fpalombini
comments.body:
EDIT: this response is in preparation for Ace interim 15-04-2020

My main question is: what does this consideration applies to? It could apply to the joining process and to POST to pub-key (where the node post a new public key to the KDC). These are quite perpendicular though (1 -> joining, 2 -> pub-key, 3 -> not supported), so I am not sure what this adds… This could be covering the join – leave – rejoin with the same token process, that is not very well covered right now, is that something we need to expand on?

> I believe that one needs to look at the following cases:

> No public key with the right parameters has been associated with the token - in this case both the key and proof are required

What we do say is that key and proof of possession are required during join process if KDC collects and distribute keys, and the client is a sender. So one key will always be associated with the token. 1 is a quite convoluted way to say: “always at joining” (which we already say…) or is this supposed to cover another case?


> One public key with the right parameters has been associated with the token - in this case the following would seem to be fine a) neither are present, b) just the key is present (proof already has been done), c) both are present

Are we talking about after joining, posting a new pub key to the KDC? Then both are needed. Unless the key is the same…in which case it is useless to repost the same to pub-key.

> Multiple public keys with the right parameters have been associated with the token - In this case the following would seem to be fine a) just the key is present (proof has already been done) or b) both are present

The KDC only keeps one public key per node (see pub-key handler), this is not supported. In what case would the client want to associate more than one key? Is this something we want?


> Such a change would seem to maximize the number of times that the public key can be omitted and an even greater number of times the proof can be omitted. In the event that the proof is needed, the error would return a new server nonce to be used in the re-sent join message.

I think right now we already cover the case where the key and proof MUST be sent in each section. What are we missing?

comments.author: jimsch
comments.body: If I have a token that allows access to multiple groups, once I have done the POP on the signing key for that token, that POP can be propagated forward to any other group join which uses the same token.  I might end up with multiple keys for the single token with different keys.  This POP could potentially be propagated forward as tokens are updated.

comments.author: fpalombini
comments.body:
I had to think about this a bit (and go over it with Marco) but I see the problem now: the issue is not with the name itself, but with the *purpose* of the parameter. By defining a *general* parameter, we are opening up for interoperability issues between applications that use this same parameter in 2 different applications running at the same time. The problem is then how to differentiate between those 2 (which one is used with each application). It could be solved, but I guess it's not worth the headache. I will remove the generality (make it specialised to ace key groupcomm) and change the name to reflect that.

(Just for record, the reason for wanting to register a more general rsnonce is that we are already registering client and server nonces with specific functions in the OSCORE profile, and the cnonce defined in ace also has a very specific function, so I was thinking let's register *one* parameter that can be used as rs nonce by the application and let the application decide how to use it, rather than keep registering nonces for specific functions).

issues.title: Idempotency of joining interface
issues.author: chrysn
issues.body:
I didn't read the latest version, but there's a point that should be considered (and I can check it later if you want to assign it to me; then thisis a note-to-self):

For CoAP implementations it's convenient if resources are implementable in an idempotent way (preferably even being allowed to send the same response again) -- as this allows the server to forego request deduplication.

Now for a joining resource, we can't provide that long-term (like we do with RD), as joining a group needs to always produce a new KID (because it allows the new member to zero-initialize all its replay windows, and to start with a sender sequence number of 0, both of which must only be done once).

It would still be nice to allow idempotent implementation for some (common) cases. This requires a mandate to the client that it only create a given GID/KID context once. The client can't provide that in the *general* case -- it might just be starting up, request the context, start using it, get powercycled, send request it again, use the response, and BOOM goes the crypto.

However, when an ACE profile is used that has some forms of sessions (the nonces of ace-oscore-profile, or the ... well, sessions (epochs?) for DTLS), it may be permissible to allow idempotent implementations that send the same response just again, *if* clients can be required to not initialize a KID context twice from responses of the same session with the GM. That seems to be a reasonable thing to ask from the clients; it's probably more work specifying than implementing.

---

Granted, it's a small optimization, so feel free to turn this down if it sounds excessive. It may easily be that this is just the point where even stacks that previously got away with requiring resource idempotency just need deduplication.

comments.author: chrysn
comments.body:
After a bit of live discussion: not worth it.

An implementation that does all those nitty gritty checking of the details (and coordinate them with the clients) may still manage do them, but making them required for every implementer to consider would be extraneous.

issues.title: ACE scope semantics: CBOR file-magic
issues.author: chrysn
issues.body:
Following up on IETF113 discussion, I think that the "extended scope format" can be vastly simplified by using [cbor-file-magic](https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/draft-ietf-cbor-file-magic/):

Rather than specifying a new format and registry for scopes, the scopes within an audience that employs this mechanism would be disambiguated just like file formats. (They have common properties: Everybody assumes that their semantics are known from the context, but in the odd case they are not, eg. because an audience is used with different kinds of scopes).

Rather than becoming

```
extended_scope = #6.TBD_TAG(<< [semantics, scope] >>)
```

the extended scope could just be
```
extended_scope = #6.TAG_FOR_THESE_SEMANTICS(scope)
```

which, if TAG_FOR_THESE_SEMANTICS is allocated following the recommendations of cbor-file-magic (I guess it'd forego using the self-describing tag `#6.55799()` around it) equivalent to prefixing the encoded scope with 5 bytes specific to that tag. In particular, if for the scopes' semantics a content format is allocated (and there is already 290 for AIF with the default `;Toid=URI-local-part;Tperm=REST-method-set`), the tag is even already allocated, and if other AIF generalizations allocate their own content format, they also get the tag automatically.

The only down side I see is that the scope claims might grow in size, depending on the precise numbers allocated. But for example, if a 1+1 tag were chosen for the current TBD_TAG, depending on the length of the inner encoding, this might already be just as good or even better.

comments.author: marco-tiloca-sics
comments.body:
Thanks for the good observation and input, I think it would be a good change!

When the "extended scope format" was added to -ace-key-groupcomm, the registration of one tag only and of on-demand semantics integers ended up preferred, compared to opening for the registration of multiple CBOR tags. But on the other hand I think all you've mentioned was not around yet :-)

> which, if TAG_FOR_THESE_SEMANTICS is allocated following the recommendations of cbor-file-magic (I guess it'd forego using the self-describing tag #6.55799() around it) equivalent to prefixing the encoded scope with 5 bytes specific to that tag.

Yes, TAG_FOR_THESE_SEMANTICS would be from the 4-byte range, and there is no need to further use the tag 55799.

> In particular, if for the scopes' semantics a content format is allocated (and there is already 290 for AIF with the default ;Toid=URI-local-part;Tperm=REST-method-set), the tag is even already allocated,

Yes, if scope uses exactly Generic AIF, the value of  TAG_FOR_THESE_SEMANTICS is 1668546850=1668546560+290.

Some guideline and pointer to -cbor-file-magic can be added for a more general case not relying on AIF.

> and if other AIF generalizations allocate their own content format, they also get the tag automatically.

Yes, for example the document -ace-key-groupcomm-oscore is defining the new data model AIF-OSCORE-GROUPCOMM [0] and registering a corresponding content-format, so it would also automatically have the corresponding value for its TAG_FOR_THESE_SEMANTICS.

> The only down side I see is that the scope claims might grow in size, depending on the precise numbers allocated. But for example, if a 1+1 tag were chosen for the current TBD_TAG, depending on the length of the inner encoding, this might already be just as good or even better.

I think it's more likely to be even better.

[0] As also discussed at IETF 113, that same data model would cover both the "user" scope entries defined in -ace-key-groupcomm-oscore and the "admin" scope entries defined in -ace-oscore-gm-admin, as possible to coexist in the same scope claim. The type of the different scope entries is distinguishable thanks to the least significant bit in their Tperm value, which would also have this meaning already from the revised definition of the data model.

issues.title: Guidelines to group members failing incoming message processing
issues.author: marco-tiloca-sics
issues.body:
Section 4.8.1.1 "Retrieve Group and Individual Keying Material"

TL;DR: Provide more guidelines for a group member that keeps failing to decrypt/verify incoming messages, even after having retrieved the latest keying material from the KDC. The group member can try to retrieve the authentication credentials of the message senders. If that still does not work, the group member can try to retrieve the authentication credential of the KDC.


Following the multiple failed decryption and verification of an incoming message and the retrieval of the latest group keying material, the group member may retrieve the group keying material that it is already storing.

In such a case, the failed decryption might be due to the message sender and/or the KDC that has changed its authentication credential.

Hence, the group member can follow-up by retrieving the authentication credential of the message sender (see Section 4.4). If such an authentication credential has not changed compared to the currently stored one, then the group member can further follow-up by retrieving the authentication credential of the KDC (see Section 4.5).

issues.title: Clarify meaning of 'cred_fmt'
issues.author: marco-tiloca-sics
issues.body:
Section 3.3.1 "'sign_info' Parameter" of version -16 says:

`The fifth element 'cred_fmt' parameter is either a CBOR integer indicating the format of authentication credentials used in the groups identified by the 'gname' values, or has value the CBOR simple value "null" (0xf6) indicating that the KDC does not act as repository of authentication credentials for group members. Its acceptable integer values are taken from the 'Label' column of the "COSE Header Parameters" registry [COSE.Header.Parameters]. It is REQUIRED of the application profiles to define specific values to use for this parameter, consistently with the acceptable formats of authentication credentials (REQ6).`

It should better say:

The fifth element 'cred_fmt' parameter is either a CBOR integer indicating the format of authentication credentials used in the groups identified by the 'gname' values, or has value the CBOR simple value "null" (0xf6) indicating that the KDC does not act as repository of authentication credentials for group members. Its acceptable integer values are taken from the 'Label' column of the "COSE Header Parameters" registry [COSE.Header.Parameters]**, with some of those values also indicating the type of container to use for exchanging the authentication credentials with the KDC (e.g., a chain or bag of certificates)**. It is REQUIRED of the application profiles to define specific values to use for this parameter, consistently with the acceptable formats of authentication credentials (REQ6).

issues.title: Fix the CDDL definition of 'sign_info_entry'
issues.author: marco-tiloca-sics
issues.body:
In version -16, Section 3.3.1 "'sign_info' Parameter" includes the definition

OLD
```
sign_info_entry =
[
  id : gname / [ + gname ],
  sign_alg : int / tstr,
  sign_parameters : [ any ],
  sign_key_parameters : [ any ],
  cred_fmt = int / null
]

gname = tstr
```

Instead, it should be

NEW
```
sign_info_entry =
[
  id : gname / [ + gname ],
  sign_alg : int / tstr,
  sign_parameters : [ any ],
  sign_key_parameters : [ + parameter : any ],
  cred_fmt : int / null
]


gname = tstr
```

Also, Appendix B.1  "Extensibility for Future COSE Algorithms" includes the definition

OLD
```
sign_info_entry =
[
  id : gname / [ + gname ],
  sign_alg : int / tstr,
  sign_parameters : [ alg_capab_1 : any,
                      alg_capab_2 : any,
                      ...,
                      alg_capab_N : any],
  sign_capab_1 : [ any ],
  sign_capab_2 : [ any ],
  ...,
  sign_capab_N : [ any ],
  cred_fmt = int / null
]

gname = tstr
```

Instead, it should be

NEW
```
sign_info_entry =
[
  id : gname / [ + gname ],
  sign_alg : int / tstr,
  sign_parameters : [ * alg_capab : any ],
  * sign_capab : [ * capab : any ],
  cred_fmt : int / null
]


gname = tstr
```
